title: 114_s2193
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Illegal Reentry Act" or "Kate's Law" and includes increased penalties for reentry of removed aliens. Section 276 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include stricter regulations for aliens who reenter the United States after being denied admission or removed. The Secretary of Homeland Security has allowed certain aliens to reapply for admission, while others must prove they did not need advance consent. Violators may face fines, imprisonment, or both. Additionally, aliens with prior convictions for drug or violent crimes may face stricter penalties for reentering the US after removal. Aliens who have been excluded or removed from the United States and reenter without permission may face fines and up to 10 years imprisonment. Aliens who reenter the United States without permission after being removed or denied admission may face fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. Aliens who reenter the United States without permission after being removed or denied admission may face fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. The term 'removal' includes any agreement in which an alien stipulates to removal during a criminal trial. Additionally, aliens convicted of an aggravated felony before removal or with at least two prior illegal reentries face a mandatory minimum prison sentence of five to 20 years. Aliens who reenter the United States without permission after being removed or denied admission may face fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. The term 'removal' includes any agreement in which an alien stipulates to removal during a criminal trial. Additionally, aliens convicted of an aggravated felony before removal or with at least two prior illegal reentries face a mandatory minimum prison sentence of five to 20 years. In subsection (d), the changes involve replacing references to specific sections and officials with updated ones.
